Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to James E. Freitag is "Applications of model theory to geometry and algebra." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California, Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Thomas Scanlon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Freitag's project centered around the application of model theoretic ideas in algebraic differential equations. Model theory is the study of definable sets; as one moves through different mathematical contexts, the meaning of definable specializes to the setting. For instance, in the theory of algebraic differential equations, definable sets are given by differential polynomial equations and inequalities. The theory is complicated enough that the general tools developed in model theory have played a tremendous role in the development of results in differential algebra. This project centers around that development, along with generalizing results from differential algebra to the model theoretic context. The passage of ideas back and forth from model theory to differential algebra played a central role in this project. 

Freitag's project also yielded results of a diophantine nature. By analyzing the differential equations satisfied by the j-function, an analytic map related to elliptic curves, Freitag and Scanlon were able to prove results about the intersection of certain arithmetically defined sets (isogeny classes of elliptic curves). 

Freitag's project also touched on several problems which affect computational aspects of differential algebra, including differential analogs of Luroth's theorem and the Nullestellensatz. 

The broader impacts of this project are derived primarily from the training of future mathematicians and public outreach. The project allowed Freitag to participate in the 2014 MSRI thematic program, which involved numerous lectures for public audiences and general mathematical audiences.
